row.title: NSDB Contact and Staff
row.field_page_description: Contact and staff information for NCI's Nanotechnology System and Devices Branch.
row.field_feature_card_description: Contact and staff information for NCI's Nanotechnology System and Devices Branch.
row.field_list_description: Contact and staff information for NCI's Nanotechnology System and Devices Branch.
row.field_browser_title: Contact the Nanotechnology System and Devices Branch (NSDB)

row.title: Nanotechnology in Cancer Research
row.field_page_description: The NCI Office of Cancer Nanotechnology Research has had a major impact on bringing novel nano-enabled solutions through the pre-clinical space. The strategic framework of this effort is presented here.
row.field_feature_card_description: The NCI Office of Cancer Nanotechnology Research has had a major impact on bringing novel nano-enabled solutions through the pre-clinical space. The strategic framework of this effort is presented here.
row.field_list_description: The NCI Office of Cancer Nanotechnology Research has had a major impact on bringing novel nano-enabled solutions through the pre-clinical space. The strategic framework of this effort is presented here.
row.field_browser_title: Nanotechnology in Cancer Research

row.title: NSDB Partners and Collaborators
row.field_page_description: The Nanodelivery Systems and Devices Branch at NCI partners with many commercial entities in order to enahance acceleration of nanotechnology in cancer. Find out more here about these programs.
row.field_feature_card_description: Translation of nanotechnology for cancer to the clinic has many hurdles. The NSDB partners with private, academic, and government entities to promote commercialization of nanotechnology for cancer applications.
row.field_list_description: Translation of nanotechnology for cancer to the clinic has many hurdles. The NSDB partners with private, academic, and government entities to promote commercialization of nanotechnology for cancer applications.
row.field_browser_title: NSDB Partners and Collaborators

row.title: Related NCI Initiatives
row.field_page_description: The NCI has many initiatives that help to propel the next generation of enabling technologies for cancer. Find links to these initiatives and programs here.
row.field_browser_title: Related NCI Initiatives

row.title: Current Nanotechnology Treatments
row.field_page_description: Several nanotechnology-based cancer drug therapies have been approved by the FDA and are already on the market.
row.field_feature_card_description: As far back as 1995, nanotechnology has offered clinicians novel tools to treat patients. Find a list of the currently approved nano-enabled therapeutics here.
row.field_list_description: As far back as 1995, nanotechnology has offered clinicians novel tools to treat patients. Find a list of the currently approved nano-enabled therapeutics here.
row.field_browser_title: Current Nanotechnology Treatments

row.title: Publications and Presentations
row.field_page_description: The Alliance has funded 1,250 researchers and published nearly 3,000 articles.
row.field_feature_card_description: The NSDB routinely publishes reports, strategic peer-reviewed manuscripts, and subject matter expertise papers relative to our myriad of interdisciplinary backgrounds. These papers are listed on this page.
row.field_list_description: The Nanodelivery Systems and Devices Branch routinely publishes reports, strategic peer-reviewed manuscripts, and subject matter expertise papers relative to our myriad of interdisciplinary backgrounds. These papers are listed on this page.
row.field_browser_title: Publications and Presentations

row.title: Data Sharing
row.field_page_description: Data-sharing is an important component to guarantee the best use of publically funded research. The Office of Cancer Nanotechnology Research maintains the CaNanoLab for exactly this purpose.
row.field_feature_card_description: Communicating new discoveries and sharing data is of critical importance to realize the full potential of nanotechnology in the treatment and diagnosis of cancer.
row.field_list_description: A well-organized, collaborative system of data sharing is critical in the translation of nanotechnology research into commercially viable therapeutics and diagnostics to treat patients.
row.field_browser_title: Nanomaterial Data Sharing

row.title: Nanotechnology Clinical Trials
row.field_page_description: Nanotechnology has made much progress in the last 20 years and continues to advance into the clinic. Find out here the current clinical trials for nanotechnologies targeting cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: Nanotechnology continues to progress into the clinic with more advanced tools than before and for more clinical indications or tumor types. Find a list of current clinical trials actively recruiting patients for these novel solutions.
row.field_list_description: Nanotechnology continues to progress into the clinic with more advanced tools than before and for more clinical indications or tumor types. Find a list of current clinical trials actively recruiting patients for these novel solutions.
row.field_browser_title: Nanotechnology Clinical Trials

row.title: Cal Tech & UCLA — Nanosystems Biology Cancer Center (NSBCC)
row.field_short_title: Cal Tech & UCLA — Nanosystems Biology Cancer Center
row.field_page_description: Designs and develops nanotherapies and nanotech tools to guide selection of combination cancer immunotherapy and targeted therapy treatments for brain cancers and melanoma.
row.field_feature_card_description: Designs and develops nanotherapies and nanotech tools to guide selection of combination cancer immunotherapy and targeted therapy treatments for brain cancers and melanoma.
row.field_list_description: Designs and develops nanotherapies and nanotech tools to guide selection of combination cancer immunotherapy and targeted therapy treatments for brain cancers and melanoma.
row.field_browser_title: Nanosystems Biology Cancer Center (NSBCC)
row.field_card_title: Cal Tech & UCLA — Nanosystems Biology Cancer Center

row.title: NSDB News
row.field_page_description: Find the latest news about NCI’s Nanodelivery Systems and Devices Branch.
row.field_feature_card_description: Find the latest news about NCI’s Nanodelivery Systems and Devices Branch.
row.field_list_description: Find the latest news about NCI’s Nanodelivery Systems and Devices Branch.
row.field_browser_title: OCNR News

row.title: Stanford University — Center of Cancer Nanotechnology Excellence for Translational Diagnostics (CCNE-TD)
row.field_short_title: Stanford University — Center of Cancer Nanotechnology Excellence for Translational Diagnostics
row.field_page_description: The Center of Cancer Nanotechnology Excellence for Translational Diagnostics, which forms the third cycle CCNE Program at Stanford University, is a consortium that has three highly synchronized Projects and three Cores.
row.field_feature_card_description: Develops and utilizes in vitro nanosensors and in vivo molecular imaging tools to advance methods in earlier detection of aggressive cancers as well as monitoring response to therapy for both prostate and lung cancers.
row.field_list_description: The overarching focus is to develop and utilize in vitro nanosensors and in vivo molecular imaging tools to advance methods in earlier detection of aggressive cancers as well as monitoring response to therapy for both prostate and lung cancers.
row.field_browser_title: Center of Cancer Nanotechnology Excellence for Translational Diagnostics
row.field_card_title: Stanford University — Center of Cancer Nanotechnology Excellence for Translational Diagnostics

row.title: Case Western Reserve University —Treatment of Glioblastoma Using Chain-Like Nanoparticles
row.field_short_title: Case Western Reserve University — Treatment of Glioblastoma Using Chain-Like Nanoparticles
row.field_page_description: To overcome the limitations of current drugs to treat brain tumors, Case Western University seeks to integrate the unique features of a chain-like nanoparticle with the appropriate combination of complementary drugs.
row.field_feature_card_description: Synergistic activity of of iron oxide nanospheres and a drug-loaded liposomes targeted to GBM vasculature and glioma stem cells will facilitate effective treatment and ultimately eradication of the disease using a safe dose of the drugs.
row.field_list_description: Synergistic activity of of iron oxide nanospheres and a drug-loaded liposomes targeted to GBM vasculature and glioma stem cells will facilitate effective treatment and ultimately eradication of the disease using a safe dose of the drugs.
row.field_browser_title: Case Western Reserve University — Treatment of Glioblastoma Using Chain-Like Nanoparticles
row.field_card_title: Case Western Reserve University — Treatment of Glioblastoma Using Chain-Like Nanoparticles

row.title: Sloan Kettering and Cornell University — MSKCC-Cornell Center for Translation of Cancer Nanomedicine
row.field_short_title: Sloan Kettering and Cornell University — MSKCC-Cornell Center for Translation of Nanomedicine
row.field_page_description: The focus of the Memorial Sloan Kettering and Cornell University Center of Cancer Nanotechnology Excellence is presented here.
row.field_feature_card_description: Advancment and translation of a suite of ultrasmall (<10 nm) fluorescent silica organic hybrid nanoparticles, Cornell dots, with tunable size, brightness, and geometry that will dramatically impact diagnosis and treatment of melanoma and more.
row.field_list_description: Advancment and translation of a suite of ultrasmall (<10 nm) fluorescent silica organic hybrid nanoparticles, Cornell dots, with tunable size, brightness, and geometry that will dramatically impact diagnosis and treatment of melanoma and more.
row.field_browser_title: MSKCC-Cornell Center for Translation of Cancer Nanomedicine
row.field_card_title: Sloan Kettering and Cornell University — MSKCC-Cornell Center for Translation of Nanomedicine

row.title: Training Grants
row.field_page_description: The NCI offers funding opportunities for the next generation of scientists to be trained. Find out about recent opportunities for training here.
row.field_feature_card_description: Funding for specific research and training opportunities within the field of cancer nanotechnology as well as fields that contain much cross-sectional overlap to the field.
row.field_list_description: Funding for specific research and training opportunities within the field of cancer nanotechnology as well as fields that contain much cross-sectional overlap to the field.
row.field_browser_title: Training Grants

row.title: Research Published by NCI Alliance
row.field_page_description: The NCI Alliance for Nanotechnology in Cancer has published much exciting and impactful research over the years. Find here a list of all of these listed in PubMed and others across the field of Cancer Nanotechnology.
row.field_feature_card_description: Published research is the cornerstone of scientific endeavors. The Alliance has a strong track record for publishing high-impact science and engineering.
row.field_list_description: Published research is the cornerstone of scientific endeavors. The Alliance has a strong track record for publishing high-impact science and engineering.
row.field_browser_title: Published Research - NCI Alliance for Nanotechnology in Cancer

row.title: Northwestern University — Nucleic Acid-Based Nanoconstructs for the Treatment of Cancer
row.field_short_title: Northwestern University — Nucleic Acid-Based Nanoconstructs for the Treatment of Cancer
row.field_page_description: Focuses on the design, synthesis, characterization, and development of spherical nucleic acid constructs as effective nanotherapeutic, single-entity agents for the treatment of glioblastoma multiforme and prostate cancers.
row.field_feature_card_description: Focuses on the design, synthesis, characterization, and development of spherical nucleic acid constructs as effective nanotherapeutic, single-entity agents for the treatment of glioblastoma multiforme and prostate cancers.
row.field_list_description: Focuses on the design, synthesis, characterization, and development of spherical nucleic acid constructs as effective nanotherapeutic, single-entity agents for the treatment of glioblastoma multiforme and prostate cancers.
row.field_browser_title: Nucleic Acid-Based Nanoconstructs
row.field_card_title: Northwestern University — Nucleic Acid-Based Nanoconstructs for the Treatment of Cancer

row.field_page_description: Find specific research opportunities relevant to nanotechnology and cancer.
row.field_feature_card_description: Find other specific research opportunities relevant to technology and cancer.

row.title: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill — Nano Approaches to Modulate Host Cell Response for Cancer Therapy
row.field_short_title: University of North Carolina — Nano Approaches to Modulate Host Cell Response for Cancer
row.field_page_description: The Carolina Center of Cancer Nanotechnology Excellence (CCNE) is an NCI-funded multidisciplinary collaboration among a range of disciplines using nano approaches for cancer disease management and treatment.
row.field_feature_card_description: Will exploit host responses by way of nanoscale approaches for disease management and treatment of melanoma and lung cancer.
row.field_list_description: Will exploit host responses by way of nanoscale approaches for disease management and treatment of melanoma and lung cancer.
row.field_browser_title: Nano Approaches to Modulate Host Cell Response
row.field_card_title: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill — Nano Approaches to Modulate Host Cell Response

row.title: University of California, Los Angeles & Cedars-Sinai Medical Center — Thermoresponsive NanoVelcro CTC Purification System for Prostate Cancer Profiling
row.field_short_title: UCLA — Thermoresponsive NanoVelcro CTC Purification System for Prostate Cancer Profiling
row.field_page_description: The focus of the UCLA Innovative Research in Cancer Nanotechnology is presented here.
row.field_feature_card_description: Thermoresponsive (TR)-NanoVelcro circulating tumor cell (CTC) purification system for use in the liquid biopsy of patient response to therapeutics and cancer progression.
row.field_list_description: Thermoresponsive (TR)-NanoVelcro circulating tumor cell (CTC) purification system for use in the liquid biopsy of patient response to therapeutics and cancer progression.
row.field_browser_title: Thermoresponsive NanoVelcro CTC Purification System for Prostate Cancer Profiling
row.field_card_title: UCLA — Thermoresponsive NanoVelcro CTC Purification System for Prostate Cancer Profiling

row.title: Apply for the Alliance
row.field_page_description: The NCI Alliance for Nanotechnology in Cancer continues to accept applications for many of its program elements. Find out details on the application process here.
row.field_feature_card_description: NCI Alliance funding is by way of many grant mechanisms of the National Institutes of Health. Appliaction details for current Alliance funding is listed here.
row.field_list_description: NCI Alliance funding is by way of many grant mechanisms of the National Institutes of Health. Appliaction details for current Alliance funding is listed here.

row.title: University of Chicago — Nanoscale Metal-organic Frameworks for Light Triggered and X-ray Induced Photodynamic Therapy of Head and Neck Cancers
row.field_short_title: University of Chicago — Nanoscale Metal-organic Frameworks
row.field_page_description: This project addresses the unmet needs in developing highly efficient and safe nanoparticle PSs that can have much broader clinical applications for cancer by Near-IR triggered PDT and X-ray induced PDT (X-PDT).
row.field_feature_card_description: Addressing an unmet need in developing highly efficient and safe nanoparticles that can have much broader clinical applications for cancer by Near-IR triggered PDT and X-ray induced PDT (X-PDT) as well radioimmunotherapy.
row.field_list_description: Addressing an unmet need in developing highly efficient and safe nanoparticles that can have much broader clinical applications for cancer by Near-IR triggered PDT and X-ray induced PDT (X-PDT) as well radioimmunotherapy.
row.field_browser_title: University of Chicago — Nanoscale Metal-organic Frameworks
row.field_card_title: Chicago &m Nanoscale Metal-organic Frameworks for Light Triggered X-ray Induced Photodynamic Therapy

row.title: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill —Targeted Core Shell Nanogels for Triple Negative Breast Cancer
row.field_short_title: University of North Carolina — Targeted Core Shell Nanogels for Triple Negative Breast Cancer
row.field_page_description: Improves systemic therapies of cancer using soft nanomaterials that can penetrate deep into tumors and deliver potent anticancer agents to targeted cancer cells.
row.field_feature_card_description: Improves systemic therapies of cancer using soft nanomaterials that can penetrate deep into tumors and deliver potent anticancer agents to targeted cancer cells.
row.field_list_description: Improves systemic therapies of cancer using soft nanomaterials that can penetrate deep into tumors and deliver potent anticancer agents to targeted cancer cells.
row.field_browser_title: Targeted Core Shell Nanogels for Triple Negative Breast Cancer
row.field_card_title: UNC — Targeted Core Shell Nanogels for Triple Negative Breast Cancer

row.title: Emory University — Stroma Breaking Theranostic Nanoparticles for Targeted Pancreatic Cancer Therapy
row.field_short_title: Emory University — Stroma Breaking Theranostic Nanoparticles for Targeted Pancreatic Cancer
row.field_page_description: This project develops a dual-targeted and stroma breaking theranostic nanoparticle platform to address an unmet, clinical challenge of poor drug delivery efficiency in the application of nanomedicine to cancer therapy.
row.field_feature_card_description: This project develops a dual-targeted and stroma breaking theranostic nanoparticle platform to address an unmet, clinical challenge of poor drug delivery efficiency in the application of nanomedicine to cancer therapy.
row.field_list_description: This project develops a dual-targeted and stroma breaking theranostic nanoparticle platform to address an unmet, clinical challenge of poor drug delivery efficiency in the application of nanomedicine to cancer therapy.
row.field_browser_title: Stroma Breaking Theranostic Nanoparticles for Targeted Pancreatic Cancer Therapy
row.field_card_title: Emory University — Stroma Breaking Theranostic Nanoparticles for Targeted Pancreatic Cancer

row.title: Washington University — Center for Multiple Myeloma Nanotherapy (CNMN)
row.field_short_title: Washington University — Center for Multiple Myeloma Nanotherapy
row.field_page_description: The Washington University Center for Multiple Myeloma Nanotherapy (WU CMMN) will address overarching questions in bone malignancies, with a focus on multiple myeloma.
row.field_feature_card_description: Will enable MM treatment outcomes with minimal off-target toxicity by developing novel nanotherapeutics that combine unique drug delivery mechanisms with spatiotemporal treatment paradigms.
row.field_list_description: Will enable MM treatment outcomes with minimal off-target toxicity by developing novel nanotherapeutics that combine unique drug delivery mechanisms with spatiotemporal treatment paradigms.
row.field_browser_title: Washington University: Center for Multiple Myeloma Nanotherapy
row.field_card_title: Washington University — Center for Multiple Myeloma Nanotherapy

row.title: University of California, Davis — The Rodent Eye as a Non-Invasive Window for Understanding Cancer Nanotherapeutics
row.field_short_title: University of California, Davis — The Rodent Eye as a Non-Invasive Window to Nanotherapeutics
row.field_page_description: This project uses the mouse eye as a non-surgical window for highly efficient, optical investigation of all aspects of syngeneic or xenograft models, using a state-of-the-art ocular imaging facility, the "EyePod."
row.field_feature_card_description: This project uses the mouse eye as a non-surgical window for highly efficient, optical investigation of all aspects of syngeneic or xenograft models, using a state-of-the-art ocular imaging facility, the "EyePod."
row.field_list_description: This project uses the mouse eye as a non-surgical window for highly efficient, optical investigation of all aspects of syngeneic or xenograft models, using a state-of-the-art ocular imaging facility, the "EyePod."
row.field_browser_title: The Rodent Eye as a Non-Invasive Window for Understanding Cancer Nanotherapeutics
row.field_card_title: University of California, Davis — The Rodent Eye as a Non-Invasive Window to Nanotherapeutics

row.title: University of California, Los Angeles — Mesoporous Silica Nanoparticle Platform for Treatment of Pancreas Cancer
row.field_short_title: UCLA &mdash Multifunctional Mesoporous Silica Nanoparticle Platform for Treatment of Pancreas Cancer
row.field_page_description: This research addresses the treatment of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC).
row.field_feature_card_description: Utilizing rationally designed mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNP) to provide efficacious, safe and life-prolonging chemotherapy to pancreatic cancer patients.
row.field_list_description: Utilizing rationally designed mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNP) to provide efficacious, safe and life-prolonging chemotherapy to pancreatic cancer patients.
row.field_browser_title: Multifunctional Mesoporous Silica Nanoparticle Platform for Treatment of Pancreas Cancer

row.field_short_title: University of Texas Interdisciplinary Translational Pre/Postdoctoral Program, Cancer Nanotechnology

row.field_feature_card_description: Bridging the gap between new discoveries coming from academic labs and their translation into clinic with a multidisciplinary training program.

row.title: Benefits of Nanotechnology for Cancer
row.field_page_description: Nanotechnology offers specific benefits that will enable the future of cancer care. Find out here what these benefits are.
row.field_feature_card_description: Nanotechnology offers many possible benefits to cancer therapy, detection and diagnosis. The benefits begin by way of the fundamental properties of nanotechnology and the biological challenges of which it can help to overcome.
row.field_list_description: Nanotechnology offers many possible benefits to cancer therapy, detection and diagnosis. The benefits begin by way of the fundamental properties of nanotechnology and the biological challenges of which it can help to overcome.
row.field_browser_title: Benefits of Nanotechnology for Cancer

row.title: Masimo Corporation — Mechanical Drugs: Harnessing Cancer Aggressiveness to Overcome Its Resistance
row.field_short_title: Masimo Corporation — Mechanical Drugs: Harnessing Cancer Aggressiveness
row.field_page_description: Developing a new therapeutic approach to triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) which is based on intracellular mechanical impact generated by plasmonic nanobubbles.
row.field_feature_card_description: Developing a new therapeutic approach to triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) which is based on intracellular mechanical impact generated by plasmonic nanobubbles.
row.field_list_description: Developing a new therapeutic approach to triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) which is based on intracellular mechanical impact generated by plasmonic nanobubbles.

row.title: Earlier Detection and Diagnosis
row.field_page_description: Winning the battle in cancer is by way of its earlier detection. Find out here how nanotechnology for cancer can enable the next generation of diagnostics.
row.field_feature_card_description: Nanotechnology research is exploring new ways to detect cancer early and improve diagnosis.
row.field_list_description: In cancer, half the battle is won by its earlier detection and enhanced diagnosis. Furthmore, tools to enable precise monitoring of patient response to therapy can optimize therapy and improve patient outcomes. Find out how nanotechnology is and will continue to offer powerful solutions to these areas.
row.field_browser_title: Nanotechnology and Early Cancer Detection and Diagnosis

row.title: The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center—Targeted Therapeutics for Ovarian Cancer and its Microenvironment – Treatment and Theoretical Modeling
row.field_short_title: The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center—Targeted Therapeutics for Ovarian Cancer
row.field_page_description: Will offer nanotherapeutic formulations and novel approaches targeting multiple components of the tumor and its microenvironment, specifically for high-grade serous ovarian cancers.

row.title: Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Univeristy — Imaging of Nanotherapeutic Drug Action
row.field_short_title: Harvard Univeristy — Imaging of Nanotherapeutic Drug Action at Massachusetts General Hospital
row.field_page_description: In vivo imaging analyses of therapeutic nanoparticles (TNP), addressing key questions on nanoparticle distribution (pharmacokinetics, PK) and cellular response (pharmacodynamics, PD).
row.field_feature_card_description: In vivo imaging analyses of therapeutic nanoparticles (TNP), addressing key questions on nanoparticle distribution (pharmacokinetics, PK) and cellular response (pharmacodynamics, PD).

row.field_card_title: Harvard Univeristy — Imaging of Nanotherapeutic Drug Action at Massachusetts General Hospital

row.title: Treatment and Therapy
row.field_page_description: Nanotechnology offers the means to target therapies directly and selectively to cancerous cells and neoplasms. With these tools, clinicians can safely and effectively deliver chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and the next generation of immuno- and gene therapies to the tumor. Futhermore, surgical resection of tumors can be guided and enhanced by way of nanotechnology tools. Find out how nanotechnology will offer the next generation of our therapeutic arsenal to the patient.
row.field_feature_card_description: Nanotechnology offers the means to target therapies directly and selectively to cancerous cells and neoplasms. With these tools, clinicians can safely and effectively deliver chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and the next generation of immuno- and gene therapi
row.field_list_description: Nanotechnology offers the means to target therapies directly and selectively to cancerous cells and neoplasms. With these tools, clinicians can safely and effectively deliver chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and the next generation of immuno- and gene therapies to the tumor. Futhermore, surgical resection of tumors can be guided and enhanced by way of nanotechnology tools. Find out how nanotechnology will offer the next generation of our therapeutic arsenal to the patient.
row.field_browser_title: Nanotechnology Cancer Therapy and Treatment

row.title: Safety of Nanotechnology Cancer Treatment
row.field_page_description: Nanotechnology is a powerful tool for combating cancer. NCI's Alliance for Nanotechnology in Cancer is continuously testing the safety of this new technology.

row.title: Ohio State University and University of Kentucky — Optimizing RNA Nanoparticle's Size and Shape for Enhancing Cancer Targeting and Treatment
row.field_short_title: Ohio State University and University of Kentucky — Optimizing RNA Nanoparticles
row.field_page_description: A systematic characterization of RNA nanoparticle behavior, in vitro and in vivo, to optimize its cellular delivery to triple negative breast cancer (TNBC).

row.title: University of California, San Diego — Cancer Research in Nanotechnology (CRIN)
row.field_short_title: University of California, San Diego — Cancer Research in Nanotechnology (CRIN)
row.field_page_description: Provides trainees with a balanced combination comprehensive cancer biology, engineering, and entrepreneurship didactic training, including cancer researcher, clinical/translational cancer faculty, and practical skills in small business environments.
